title: Dorm Group Chat
openingParagraphs: Victim was found collapsed near the back gate of the university dorm at 2:14 AM. Hours before, she messaged the dorm group chat saying she felt followed, but no one replied. The message remained unread as she was later discovered unconscious beside her phone.
You were the last person she privately contacted. To uncover what happened, you must access her phone and revisit the group chat — someone from that dorm circle might be hiding something.
passcodeHintParagraph: If I had to guess… students often use important personal dates. The victim’s student ID card in her wallet shows her date of birth: *June 21, 2004*. She always joked that she used it for everything — even her locker code.
*A six–digit number tied to that date should be the key.*

title: After Hours at the Office
openingParagraphs: The victim stayed late almost every night during the project deadline. Tension had grown in the team — disputes over workload, concerns about layoffs, and arguments about who would take responsibility if things fell apart.

At 1:53 AM, the security guard found her unconscious in the meeting room. Her office phone kept receiving messages from the ‘Project-Final’ group. You've been granted temporary access to her device — the truth is somewhere in that chat history.
passcodeHintParagraph: Office folks usually rely on numbers they see every day. Her desk note shows the official *project kickoff date: November 25, 2023*. She used that date as the Wi-Fi password once — wouldn't be surprising if she reused it here.
*Convert that date into a six–digit passcode.*

title: The Neighborhood Line Group
openingParagraphs: The neighborhood Line group used to be harmless — lost pets, garage sale posts, and the usual gossip. Recently, however, arguments escalated and neighbors grew distrustful of one another.

Last night, the victim posted a blurry photo and wrote: “If anything happens to me, it’s someone from this group.” Minutes later, emergency sirens echoed outside her home. She’s now in critical condition — and the answer lies somewhere in that chat.
passcodeHintParagraph: People at home rarely complicate their passwords. A sticky note on her fridge listed the date she moved into the house: *July 20, 2018*. It was circled twice — clearly important to her.
*Try converting that date into a six–digit code.*
